data.title: The most famous person from each of New York's 62 counties
data.meta_description: Who is the most well-known person from each of New York's counties? Find out.
data.text:
Allie Healy and Johnathan Croyle

The most famous people from every county in New York

It's easy to name a few famous people from New York, but what about one person for every county in the state? We asked numerous county historians who they thought was the most recognizable person from their county.

Check out our list of 62 people that you may not know are from or have lived in these New York state counties.

The Associated Press

Albany County: Andy Rooney

The radio and TV writer was featured on the program “60 Minutes” for more than 30 years. Has was born in Albany and graduated from Albany Academy For Boys.

Flickr | Creative Commons

Allegany County: Charles Ingalls

Charles "Pa" Ingalls is the father of Laura Ingalls Wilder, the author of the "Little House on the Prairie." He was born on a farm in the North Cuba area.

Peter Kramer | The Associated Press

Broome County: Bridget Moynahan

Bridget Moynahan was born in Binghamton as Kathryn Bridget Moynahan. She is an actress, known for “I, Robot,” “Blue Bloods” and “Lord of War.”

John Wollaston | Flickr

Bronx County: Lewis Morris

According to the Bronx County historian, the most famous people from the area is Lewis Morris. He was an American landowner, developer and a signer of the Declaration of Independence.

Matt Rourke | The Associated Press

Cattaraugus County: Bill Bergey

Bill Bergey is a former American collegiate and Professional Football player. He played collegiately for Arkansas State University and then for the Cincinnati Bengals and the Philadelphia Eagles.

Flickr | Creative Commons

Cayuga County: Eric Adams

Eric Adams has been the singer of the American heavy metal band Manowar since 1980. He was born in Auburn, where he formed his first garage band.

The Associated Press

Chautauqua County: Lucille Ball

Lucille Ball was an American actress, comedienne, model, film-studio executive and producer. She was best known as the star of the self-produced sitcoms including “I Love Lucy.”

Seth Wenig | The Associated Press

Chemung County: Tommy Hilfiger

Tommy Hilfiger is an American fashion designer best known for founding the Tommy Hilfiger brand in 1985. He was born in Elmira.

Wikimedia Commons

Chenango County: Serranus Clinton Hastings

Serranus Clinton Hastings was a U.S. Congressman and later became the founder of the Hastings College of the Law at University of California.

Paul Sancya | The Associated Press

Clinton County: Jesse Boulerice

Jesse Boulerice is an American former professional ice hockey forward. Boulerice was born in Plattsburgh and played in the NHL for the Philadelphia Flyers.

The Associated Press

Columbia County: Martin Van Buren

Van Buren served a single term as the eighth President of the United States. He was born in Kinderhook.

The Associated Press

Cortland County: Ronnie James Dio

Dio grew up in Cortland before was a heavy metal singer, songwriter and musician. He fronted or founded many groups including Elf, Rainbow and Black Sabbath.

Flickr | Creative Commons

Delaware County: John Edward Murphy

John Edward "Eddie" Murphy, nicknamed "Honest Eddie," was an American baseball player who played for three different Major League teams. He was born in Hancock.

Screenshot from YouTube

Dutchess County: Ed Wood

The director Ed Wood was born in Poughkeepsie in 1924. Famous for his low-budget science fiction, horror and comedy films of the 1950s, he was awarded a “Golden Turkey Award” as Worst Director of All Time in 1980.

Sanford Myers | The Associated Press

Erie County: Chad Michael Murray

Chad Michael Murray is an American actor, known for his role in “One Tree Hill.” He was born in Buffalo.

Jordan Strauss | The Associated Press

Essex County: Lana Del Rey

Elizabeth Woolridge Grant, better known by the stage name Lana Del Rey, is a singer and songwriter. Del Rey grew up in Lake Placid.

Library of Congress

Franklin County: Fernando Cortez Beaman

Beaman was a teacher, lawyer and politician from Michigan during and after the American Civil War. He also served as a member of the House of Representatives.

Wikimedia Commons

Fulton County: Elizabeth Anne Allen

Elizabeth Anne Allen is an American actress. She is best known for her role as the witch Amy Madison on the television series "Buffy the Vampire Slayer."

Flickr | Creative Commons

Genesee County: Marc Ferrari

Marc Ferrari is an American musician and author. He is best known for his work as a guitar player in the bands Keel, Cold Sweat and Medicine Wheel.

Chuck Burton | The Associated Press

Greene County: Mickey Brantley

Mickey Brantley was an outfielder for the Seattle Mariners and later went on to be a coach for the Toronto Blue Jays and New York Mets. He was born and raised in Catskill.

Screenshot from YouTube

Hamilton County: Louis Seymour

Louis Seymour, known as "French Louie" or "Adirondack French Louie" was a guide, trapper and woodsman who died in 1915.

Flickr | Creative Commons

Herkimer County: General Nicholas Herkimer

Nicholas Herkimer was an American Patriot general during the American Revolutionary War. He later died from his injuries after the Battle of Oriskany.

Chris Young | The Associated Press

Jefferson County: Viggo Mortensen

Viggo Mortensen is a Danish-American actor who graduated from Watertown High School. Mortensen received international attention with his role in the film trilogy “The Lord of the Rings.

Evan Agostini | The Associated Press

Kings County: Barbra Streisand

Barbra Streisand is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and filmmaker who was born in Brooklyn.

Flickr | Creative Commons

Lewis County: Franklin B. Hough

Franklin Hough was a scientist, historian and the first chief of the United States Division of Forestry, the predecessor of the United States Forest Service. He was born in Martinsburg.

Screenshot from YouTube

Livingston County: Francis Bellamy

Francis Bellamy was best known for writing the original version of the American Pledge of Allegiance.

File photo

Madison County: L. Frank Baum

L. Frank Baum, was an American author known for his children's books, especially “The Wonderful Wizard of Oz.” He was born in Chittenango.

The Associated Press

Monroe County: Wendy O. Williams

Wendy O. Williams, was an American singer, songwriter and actress. Born in Webster, she was the lead singer of the punk rock band Plasmatics.

The Associated Press

Montgomery County: Kirk Douglas

Kirk Douglas is an American actor, producer, director and author. He was born in Amsterdam, NY.

The Associated Press

Nassau County: Theodore Roosevelt

Theodore Roosevelt Jr. served as the 26th President of the United States from 1901 to 1909. He was born in New York City, but resided in Oyster Bay.

Mark J. Terrill | The Associated Press

New York County: Billy Crystal

The actor, writer and comedian was born in Doctors Hospital on the Upper East Side of Manhattan in 1948.

Charles Sykes | The Associated Press

Niagara County: Kim Alexis

The model/actress was born in Lockport in 1960. She was one of the top models on the 1980s, and in 1983 and became the face of Revlon.

George Brich | The Associated Press

Oneida County: Annette Funicello

Born in Utica in 1942, the actress and singer moved to California when she was four. She rose to fame as one of the original “Mouseketeers” on the Mickey Mouse Club.

Lee Jin-Man | The Associated Press

Onondaga County: Tom Cruise

Born in Syracuse in 1962, Cruise has become one of the world’s top actors. He has been nominated for three Academy Awards and won three Golden Globes.

Harold Filan | The Associated Press

Ontario County: Humphrey Bogart

Believed to be born on Christmas Day, 1899 in New York City, the famed actor spent his summers at his parents’ cottage “Willow Brook” on Canandaigua Lake as a boy.

Charles Sykes | The Associated Press

Orange County: James Patterson

The author was born in Newburgh in 1947. He’s largely known for his novels about psychologist Alex Cross.

Courtesy of Santaclausschool.com

Orleans County: Charles Howard

Charles Howard was born in Albion in 1896, he was an actor and teacher who became famous for his portrayal of Santa Claus in department stores and parades.

Richard Shotwell | The Associated Press

Oswego County: Owen Benjamin

Owen Benjamin was born in 1980 in Oswego, New York, USA. He is an actor and writer, known for “The House Bunny,” “Sullivan & Son” and “Jack and Jill.”

Flickr | Creative Commons

Otsego County: James Fenimore Cooper

Born in 1789 In New Jersey, Cooper lived most of his life in the Cooperstown, NY area, which was founded by his father.

Flickr | Creative Commons

Putnam County: Laura Branigan

The singer/songwriter was born in Brewster in 1957. She’s best known for her 1982 hit “Gloria,” which stayed on the Billboard Hot 100 for 36 weeks.

AP Photo/Alex Brandon

Queens County: Donald Trump

Donald John Trump, born June 14, 1946, is the 45th and current President of the United States, in office since Jan. 20, 2017. Before entering politics, he was a businessman and television personality.

Reed Saxon | The Associated Press

Rensselaer County: Maureen Stapleton

The film, theater and film actress was born in Troy in 1925. She won a Tony Award for best actress in 1951 and 1971.

Matt Sayles | The Associated Press

Richmond County: Christina Aguilera

The singer/songwriter and TV personality was born on Staten Island in 1980. She earned worldwide fame in 1999 with her self-titled debut album, which included three No. 1 singles.

Evan Agostini | The Associated Press

Rockland County: Rosie O'Donnell

The comedian, actress and television personality was born in Commack, NY in 1962, but now resides in Nyack. She appeared in movies like “Sleepless in Seattle” and “A League of Their Own."

The Associated Press

St. Lawrence County: Pete Gogolak

After moving to the U.S. from Hungary in 1956, Gogolak played football at Ogdensburg High School, before studying at Cornell. He kicked for both the Buffalo Bills and New York Giants.

Peter Kramer | The Associated Press

Saratoga County: David Hyde Pierce

Pierce was born in Saratoga Springs in 1959. He is best known for playing Dr. Niles Crane on the NBC sitcom “Frasier” for which he won four Emmy Awards for Best Supporting Actor.

Gus Ruelas | The Associated Press

Schenectady County: Ann B. Davis

The actress was born in Schenectady in 1926. She won two Emmy Awards for her role in “The Bob Cummings Show,” but she will forever be remembered as Alice on “The Brady Bunch.”

Flickr | Creative Commons

Schoharie County: George Westinghouse

Born in Central Bridge in 1846, Westinghouse was an engineer and entrepreneur who earned his first patent at 19. He was one of Thomas Edison’s main rivals.

Screenshot from YouTube

Schuyler County: Cameron Argetsinger

Cameron Argetsinger was born in Youngstown, Ohio in 1921, but spent his boyhood summers visiting his grandparents in Schuyler County. He created the Watkins Glen Grand Prix Race Course which has hosted Formula One, IndyCar, and NASCAR races since it opened.

Bill Kostroun | The Associated Press

Seneca County: Tom Coughlin

The pro football coach was born in Waterloo in 1946. After playing halfback at Syracuse University, Coughlin was head coach at Boston College, and then became the inaugural coach of the Jacksonville Jaguars. He coached the New York Giants for 12 years.

Screenshot from YouTube

Steuben County: Glenn Hammond Curtiss

The aviation pioneer was born in Hammondsport in 1878. He made the first officially witnessed flight in North America, won the world’s first international air meet in France, and made the first long distance flight in the U.S. from Albany to New York City in 1910.

The Associated Press

Suffolk County: Walt Whitman

Born in Huntington on Long Island in 1819, Whitman is considered to be among America’s most influential poets, and is often called the “father of free verse.” He worked as a journalist, teacher, Civil War nurse, and published his major work, “Leaves of Grass,” with his own money.

The Associated Press

Sullivan County: Stephanie Blythe

Born in Mongaup Valley in 1970, the mezzo-soprano is considered one of the most highly respected artists of her generation. She has performed at Carnegie Hall, the Metropolitan Opera, and the Paris National Opera.

Flickr | Creative Commons

Tioga County: John D. Rockefeller

The oil industry magnate was born in Richford in 1839, and is considered to be the wealthiest American of all-time, and quite possibly the richest person in modern history.

David Valdez | The Associated Press

Tompkins County: Alex Haley

The writer was born in Ithaca in 1921. His first book was “The Autobiography of Malcolm X” in 1965. His 1976 book, “Roots: The Saga of an American Family,” was adapted by ABC as a miniseries.

Chris Pizzello | The Associated Press

Ulster County: Jimmy Fallon

Fallon was born in Brooklyn in 1974. His family moved to Saugerties, where he graduated from high school. He’s new the sixth permanent host of “The Tonight Show.”

Peter Kramer | The Associated Press

Warren County: Rachel Ray

Born in Glens Falls in 1968, the celebrity cook, television personality, and author has won three Daytime Emmy Awards for her various TV shows. She has written several cookbooks and launched a magazine in 2006.

The Associated Press

Washington County: Grandma Moses

Anna Mary Robertson Moses, known by her nickname Grandma Moses, was born in 1860 in Greenwich. The folk artist, who began painting in earnest at the age of 78, has had her work shown and sold all over the United States and the world.

File photo

Wayne County: Van Rensselaer Richmond

The Erie Canal Engineer was born in Chenango County in 1812, but was appointed Resident Engineer of the Erie Canal at Lyons in 1837. He developed innovative designs for building bridges and canal aqueducts. His technique was used to enable building of the Brooklyn Bridge.

Scott Schild | sschild@syracuse.com

Westchester County: Bill Clinton

The 42nd President of the United States purchased a home in Chappaqua with his presidency winding down, as his wife, Hillary, planned to run for one of New York’s Senate seats.

Flickr | Creative Commons

Wyoming County: Ed Don George

Born in North Java in 1905, George wrestled for St. Bonaventure and Michigan Universities. He finished fourth in his weight class in freestyle wrestling at the 1928 Olympics. Turing to pro wrestling after the Olympics, he won the AWA World Championship in December 1930.

Flickr | Creative Commons

Yates County: John Roche

The screen and stage actor was born in Penn Yan in 1893. He began his acting career in the 1910s, and landed a featured role in 1922’s “The Good Provider.” Over the course of his career he appeared in over 50 films and Broadway productions.

Thank you to the historians

A special thanks to the following historians who helped us with this list:

Lloyd Ultan, Bronx County; Michelle Henry, Chautauqua County; Rachel Dworkin, Chemung County; Pat Evans, Chenango County; Susan Perkins, Herkimer County; Jordan Walker, Jefferson County; Ron Schweiger, Kings County; Jerry Perrin, Lewis County; Amie Alden, Livingston County; Matthew Urtz, Madison County; Natalie Naylor, Nassau County; Catherine L. Emerson, Niagara County; Johanna Yaun, Orange County; Justin White, Oswego County; Michael Maloney, Schenectady County; Julie Morris, Schuyler County; Eleanor R. Silliman, Steuben County; Ned Smith, Suffolk County; Emma Sedore, Tioga County; Audrey Klinkenberg, Ulster County; Stan Cianfarano, Warren County; Loretta Bates, Washington County; Peter Evans, Wayne County; Patrick Raftery, Westchester County and Cynthia Amrhein, Wyoming County.

Pictured above: Matt Urtz, Madison County historian. Photo by John Berry.
